text: Pretty good idea especially with the new AerialConfig.app I introduced in 1.4.5 beta2 ! I can't do it at installation (I can't do anything at installation !) but I can at first launch indeed ! Thanks for the idea ! @dVIAN13 I thought I could simply pop a dialog box but those don't really exist on macos, we are already the equivalent of a dialog box (a modal sheet). So right now, maybe adding an extra tab to the panel on those older versions of macOS with a checkbox "I understand" and until you checked that, when you open preferences it will show that pane ? I'm not sure if AerialConfig.app can detect if Aerial.saver is installed, I'll think about that too as this will be another pain point. Maybe it's a bit forceful but I was very reluctant to do the AerialConfig.app thing because I knew most people won't read instructions correctly anyway (we had 2 "done" button issues in 2 days after all !) @dVIAN13 yep that's the goal, only show to people on < mojave, and only until they click the checkbox (I won't show it on upgrade, etc). I think I'll add a direct link to the config app download in the Advanced tab too. I'll remove the tab for mojave and once they click. Here's what I got so far : (obviously it won't show on mojave but that's where I made the mockup ;)) Maybe you or @SeanMSmith have opinions about the text ? It will let you fully configure Aerial. We apologize for this inconvenience. Is the build not signed ? I was pretty sure I did ? I can confirm redownloading the app. Weird thing is, it shows as signed (codesign -vd on the app file) ! I'll look into it tomorrow, must be something I missed regarding signing, maybe needs an entitlement or something, bah ! Edit : The zip needs to be signed too 😱 Will see how to do that tomorrow @28grahams Please make sure you have installed the latest version, this bug has been fixed since 1.4. Here's version 1.4.4 : https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/download/v1.4.4/Aerial.saver.zip You can read this message if you want more information on how to check your version : https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/608#issuecomment-434451106 and the project readme for instructions to uninstall any old version you may have. @nnichols14 Which folder ? And when do you see the message ? Did you try this as written in the troubleshooting section : > "You cannot use the Aerial screen saver with this version of macOS." error: Select Aerial, close System Preferences with Aerial still selected, re-open System Preferences and Aerial should now work. This is a known bug with Swift screensavers in macOS/OS X reported to Apple as rdar://25569037. Hi @PencilNotPen - Add the ability to have a separate video format on battery : Should be doable, I'll look into it for 1.4.5. - Have dark mode independent of time calculations/override : I'm unsure of how to implement that UI wise. I agree that dark mode is a bit different than the other time modes and could be cumulated, but it was quite convenient to put everything at the same level ! Maybe some checkbox like "Always show night videos on dark mode" at the bottom of the pane, with some introductory text. Maybe @SeanMSmith would have an idea of how to phrase that ? @PencilNotPen check https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/download/v1.4.5beta2/Aerial.saver.zip I also added a power saving mode (fully dim brightness + black screen) on battery/low battery. Hi @ccharlton Live desktop is just a series of still pictures, maybe a dozen but can be more, that change throughout the day. So there's not much in common in practice. We do support showing day/night videos based on time (see the Time tab) but we can't force Aerial on the desktop for now. In previous versions of macOS, you could actually run your screensaver as a desktop picture, (see here https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/37) but this is no longer possible on Mojave. We don't know of a workaround to this yet. There might be a way to directly insert ourselves in the background to replace the wallpapers, but I don't know if that's possible yet. So I looked a bit more into it, it looks like in recent versions of macOS, you can no longer put a window at wallpaper level (behind the desktop icons) but you can still have somthing that's "on top" of the wallpaper/desktop icons but behind everything else (dock, menus, all windows) I'm considering looking at this further, but would probably release this as a separate app if there's interest. I confirm ! Thanks will be fixed in next build ! Closing with 1.4.5b2 thanks ! https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/tag/v1.4.5beta2 @pws442 was it just after install ? Did you restart the System Preferences panel after install (as suggested) ? If not does it keep doing it ? Which version of Aerial are you using ? Pretty sure I fixed this in 1.4 on Mojave. Did you use 1.4.4 ? You can see version at the bottom right of the screen : ![screen shot 2018-10-29 at 13 21 05](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37544189/47649972-1f76a980-db7f-11e8-910b-1d5d50931ae2.png) If you don't, you probably have a very old version (make sure you don't have 2 aerial versions installed and mix them up, happens to me often too :)) The new version has a "earth" thumbnail on the left, whereas the old ones had a Golden Gate thumbnail. No problem, enjoy ! Hi @thomasche, this seems to happen for some (maybe all ? unsure) users of high sierra, I did notice it myself and asked around about it here : https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/586 I'll try to get some more feedback as I'm not sure it's a bug for everyone on 10.13.6 (it's definitely not happening on Mojave). For some reason it lookds like we don't have focus, which makes the textfields unusable (so margins, custom message, brightness time and custom coordinates off the top of my head). I currently have no good workaround for this but if you really want to fix something manually, you can edit the preferences .plist easily if you have Xcode to change those settings. The plist can be found here : `~/Library/Preferences/ByHost/com.JohnCoates.Aerial.{UUID}.plist` The parameters should be pretty self explanatory, if you need more help with this workaround just ask ! I'll try to ask some of our other users on 10.13.6. Edit: got another confirmation. Tried looking for a solution today but nothing yet. Edit 2: Really thought I had it, I did manage to get the controls "blue" but the textfields remain uneditable 🤯 As a workaround to this bug, starting with 1.4.5 beta 2, I provide an additional download, AerialConfig.app. This app is a standalone version of the Aerial configuration pane that you see in System Preferences. You can use this standalone App to configure Aerial instead of the System Preferences panel if you have issues with it. The file is AerialConfig.app.zip, you'll need to install the same version of the screensaver for things to work smootly. @thomasche can you get both files and give this a try please ? https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/tag/v1.4.5beta2 @KyleLeneau this look pretty awesome, huge work on linting I really appreciate it (this is my first swift project as you would have probably guessed fixing the lints 😅). I'll have a thorough look at this today and merge ASAP, many many thanks ! As far as I see, no issues with this so on we go, thanks ! I'm not convinced this is correct. Those were added by @SeanMSmith so we should ask his input. It's one thing to use specific rules for UI but when it's full sentences, there are specific rules. As far as I know, if there's no . before the ( it should be mincapped. Will wait for @SeanMSmith on this but thanks ! Thanks ! Closing this then. > I would like the option to set a custom amount of time the text stays on the screen for, not just 10 seconds or always Let me guess, you want a 5 second option that would look like what's on AppleTV ? 😅 I can see adding a 5 second option. Custom, I'm uneasy about because of the way descriptions work. A video may have several descriptions, spaced by as little as 10 or 15 seconds. That's why I use 10. Adding a custom option where you could set 30 would make little sense as it wouldn't be enforced most of the time. > Also @glouel Any way to change it from 60 mins to 1 hour? > ![screen shot 2018-10-29 at 4 37 18 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44180668/47686551-03800180-db99-11e8-8b87-e7eaa977dfcb.png) > In Brightness @NightRaider73 can you please try this for me : - if you are the last poster on a thread, and unless some time has passed (let's say a day), please edit your previous message and don't reply to yourself, you're generating a HUGE amount of notifications and that's really disturbing. Just edit your message, it's better for everyone - try to stay relatively on topic, this brightness thing is really unrelated ;) I'll be reworking that one slightly but there's a point to the minutes, so we can later auto fill that in the minutes field below. This would make things easier for me, thanks @StrangePC ? (please see my reply here too : https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/602#issuecomment-434273341) So yep, Aerial does by default : - show community descriptions - show apple descriptions - show the video name In that case there's neither a community description nor a Apple description (there are very few of these AFAIR). I'll add one for this one thanks. If you see other videos where this is the case, list them here so we can do something about them. Closing with 1.4.5b2: https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/tag/v1.4.5beta2 Can you make a picture or a screenshot of the bug ? There are some known drivers issues on High Sierra. One thing that seemed to help most users was enabling the clock on this pane : ![screen shot 2018-10-29 at 13 17 23](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37544189/47677201-c3337a00-dbbe-11e8-9c8b-1ed3becd1169.png) Check the "Show with clock" at the bottom of the screen and let me know if that helps. As far as we know, this is fixed in Mojave although that may not be of much help to you. Thanks ! I've seen a weird bug on my old Macbook Air that's stuck on 10.13.6. When you open Aerial preferences, the preferences sheet doesn't have focus. The biggest hint is that the tab bar is grey instead of blue (in focus) : ![bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37544189/47573866-a0932e00-d93e-11e8-959a-a70bc25ec4e4.png) This used to be of little impact in older versions, but with more recent ones, apart from the color thing, you simply can't type in any text field, which is an issue for custom messages, brightness duration and longitude/latitude. Does anyone else experience this on any version of macOS prior to Mojave or is it just on my system ? I've rolled back to 1.2 and the issue was already there, I tried a few things to fix it but no luck. Interesting, hopefully we'll get more data on this ! Thanks for confirmation. Been trying to look onto that one all day with no success so far. I did find one swift screensaver that doesn't have the issue, it doesn't do anything different from what I can see (the project is old swift and I need an old Xcode to try and compile it again, will look into that) So I tried a lot of stuff, even managed to get the buttons and everything get tinted, but the fields remain uneditable on High Sierra. At that point I'm thinking of a plan B, we have a separate AerialApp which is just a test app for developers, but allow you to change the settings, and it works perfectly on high sierra. So I'll just release the AerialApp as a separate optional download for High Sierra, and people can use that as a workaround to change Aerial settings. I think it's a good enough compromise as I spent a couple of days on this already for nothing. Please see here for the workaround : https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/606#issuecomment-434813082 There's no need to reopen a new issue, I get notifications for messages on closed issues and reply there. And no I can't do better than that, I suggest you read the other thread. @StrangePC Define anywhere ? As of right now you can use random corner if you don't want it to stick always at the same place. @StrangePC As far as I know it's in the left bottom corner on Apple TV ? Random position is not easy. I do, but we don't aim to copy *exactly* everything Apple does. They may, and rightly so, take offense to it. We're quite happy that they haven't so far. Adding a custom fixed position could be done, I'll put it in the list of future features to be looked at. Trying not to break everything, one "easy" option would be to allow to change the margin relative to the corner, this way it doesn't break the rest of the features. I'll keep thinking about it. @StrangePC Added the option to change the margin in beta2. Also change the default to 50/50px instead of 10/10. https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/download/v1.4.4beta2/Aerial.saver.zip Closing as fixed. Please remove your changes to the auto update. Thanks! Haha nice catch ! Indeed that's the Eiffel Tower coordinates, those were my test coordinates, forgot to remove them as I rushed that build to fix the translation crash :) I'll leave these blank with a placeholder in next build ! @dVIAN13 I put up 1.4.4 beta 1, I removed the default values for latitude longitudes (they will remain if you installed test2 though, just empty the fields) and added a number formatter that should keep inputs correct. https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/download/v1.4.4beta1/Aerial.saver.zip No worries ! - I think they use a slightly different calculation, not a coordinates issues, that may differ a bit. I use this to calculate https://github.com/ceek/solar Here, I get about a +/- 7 min difference with night shift indeed, using the "official" calculation mode. There are several ways to calculate (I was pondering adding them), but Apple is a bit between official and "civil" calculation (closer to official). See this : https://www.timeanddate.com/astronomy/different-types-twilight.html To give you an idea, civil is -/+40 compared to "official" here. My guess is Apple is using official + 1° or something like that. I'm not sure if "copying" their stuff is a good idea, although I understand the discrepancy can be troubling. Maybe I can explain it better with the multiple calculation modes (and maybe add a mode that gets close to night shift would solve the thing, as an option with civil and regular, etc). - In theory you can get coordinates through location services. This has a few issues though, the first one being I didn't manage to get it to work in my early testing 😅 But even then, one issue is you may get a prompt which can be an issue as I need to be able to rely on Aerial starting with no UI when the screensaver launches itself. I can't prompt there, and there can be reasons why you may need to get reprompted (maybe you disabled location services or something and I need to ask permission again). That's why I went with night shift, it's much easier, there's no permissions and it fixes itself if you travel. It's probably possible to implement something robust for the other mode with CoreLocation but that's probably more work than I wish to undertake right now as the permission thing is not easy to fix I think, especially since it's a fallback solution for older macs. - Arg, that one is my fault 🙈 It's the thing that make sure you don't put letters in that does that, I'll fix it in next version ;) @dVIAN13 so according to these guys : https://www.timeanddate.com The "official" mode that the library I used give are the "correct" times (modulo a few seconds). The library uses 90.83 degrees to calculate that value (per https://www.timeanddate.com/astronomy/different-types-twilight.html). If I use 90°, I get pretty much exactly the values from night shift, so it looks like Apple rounded that value :) What I did for beta 2 is put a new menu right of the lat/long to pick the calculation mode with these values: - Strict (0°) - Official (0.83°) - Civil (6°) - Nautical (12°) - Astronomical (18°) Strict is the Apple like one, I'll keep Official as default, and add a help bubble describing the values. beta 2 : https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/download/v1.4.4beta2/Aerial.saver.zip Yep it's about 7 mins diff here between official and strict, but strict is about even to night shift, that's why I put it there. Personally I prefer Civil so far but I think it's gonna be season dependent ! You can look here https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/580#issuecomment-433134834 about the difficulty to get user coordinates, in theory it's easy but bit of a mess with permissions. Maybe some day I'll get to it. It's fairly easy to input them from maps as a user (well, it's a bit of a mess, you need to right click your location, send to mail, then extract coordinates from the link that's in mail 😱). It's much easier from other sources, or maybe some geocoding (input your location, get coordinates). I may look at that one as an easy cope-out ;) Getting user location programmatically afaik requires permission which is messy (but very good from a user stand point, just messy for our very specific usage). > @glouel So does it give you the correct coordinates? > Or do you have to get them from maps? I don't get your question. This is a manual option for now yes, where you have to enter your coordinates yourself. It's a fallback mode for those who don't have nightshift. > Perhaps (for the future) a button in Aerial's Time pane to "Get current coordinates", so that any permissions dialog will appear only when the user has manually requested the current coordinates. Yep that's what I'm looking at. CoreLocation on MacOS is a bit weird though, we'll see where I get with this. Ideally a button to get once and only once, and a checkbox for "try to check" that would try to get location when the screensaver starts for those that move around with their macs. @SeanMSmith & @dVIAN13 After looking for pretty much everything, and finding a way to make it work on Mojave only, it's just that using location services on MacOS **requires** that the app/plugin is signed. This isn't documented as far as I know and kept me looking everywhere (and finding that "workaround" on Mojave which I don't use). So in beta 4 I've added a small button next to lat/long : ![capture d ecran 2018-10-28 a 16 12 21](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37544189/47617869-53dd5d80-dacc-11e8-9484-3b2d9495270b.png) It will autofill for you based on your coordinates after asking for permission (probably once per build as far as I see). Can you let me know if that works for you? This should work on anything macOS > 10.6 If that works well, I might move that option up above night shift in the dialog, as I think it's better for most people to be able to calculate using your favorite method. beta 4 : https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/download/v1.4.4beta4/Aerial.saver.zip @SeanMSmith I probably wasn't clear, but with a signed build this should work on anything > 10.6. I don't use the Mojave only workaround, but the builds absolutely need to be signed for it to work (beta 4 is signed so should be ok for you, works on my MBA on 10.13.6 here). Will fix tomorrow thanks! > Getting my current coordinates works well in High Sierra (and the coordinates are very close to those shown in Apple Maps - they diverge at the fourth decimal place, which is close enough). Good ! Core Location gets pretty close usually, it's really good (considering the lack of GPS on Macs) > 1. Change "Today's" to "Today’s" (i.e. use a proper apostrophe) Is that the default apostrophe on QWERTY keyboard ? > 2. Don't capitalize "sunrise" and "sunset" > 3. More importantly, when the user has chosen to calculate from Civil, Nautical, or Astronomical, then change "Today’s sunrise" to "Today’s dawn" and change "Today’s sunset" to "Today’s dusk". Ok. > The help text should probably also be changed to make clear that Civil, Nautical, and Astronomical are ways of calculating the time of dawn and of dusk, not of sunrise and sunset. Perhaps something like the following: > > There are two ways to calculate the sunset and sunrise time: > > * Strict (0°): Calculate when the center of the Sun crosses the horizon > * Official (0.83°) : Calculate when the Sun completely crosses the horizon > > Or instead of sunrise and sunset, you can pick from three options for the time of dawn and dusk: > > * Civil (6°) : Calculate when the natural sunlight stops/starts requiring artificial light compensation > * Nautical (12°) : Calculate when stars stop/start being seen > * Astronomical (18°) : Calculate the point when the sun no longer interferes with astronomical observations > > (Note also that I have suggested swapping "start/stop" for "stop/start" in the help text above to correspond with dawn/dusk, adding "center of" to the definition of Strict, and correcting the spelling of "interfere".) Added as is, thanks ! I also moved up coordinate mode on top of the panel as the preferred method. ![aerial144](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37544189/47652847-58b31780-db87-11e8-9b72-c65a2686d7a3.jpg) (sorry for the spam, using this for the new screenshots) ![screen shot 2018-10-29 at 13 17 23](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37544189/47649971-1f76a980-db7f-11e8-97be-d1f90b943c9d.png) ![screen shot 2018-10-29 at 13 21 05](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37544189/47649972-1f76a980-db7f-11e8-910b-1d5d50931ae2.png) ![screen shot 2018-10-29 at 13 24 36](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37544189/47649973-1f76a980-db7f-11e8-8aef-301307d48fa2.png) ![screen shot 2018-10-29 at 13 24 46](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37544189/47649974-1f76a980-db7f-11e8-8339-3f0424652b8c.png) ![screen shot 2018-10-29 at 13 25 10](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37544189/47649975-200f4000-db7f-11e8-9e8b-f75c4a5ebde4.png) > > > 1. Change "Today's" to "Today’s" (i.e. use a proper apostrophe) > > > > > > Is that the default apostrophe on QWERTY keyboard ? > > The default apostrophe on a QWERTY keyboard is “ ' ”, what is sometimes called a “typewriter apostrophe.” > > See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apostrophe#Typographic_form and the following two sections, in particular https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apostrophe#Entering_apostrophes. Ha, didn't know about the history of it, the ink saving thing, kinda crazy come to think of it that it never changed ! In programming ' is also very much used which probably explains why it never went to be the default apostrophe. > On a Mac, pressing Option-Shift-] is the easiest way to type a proper “typographic apostrophe” (if your word processor doesn’t automatically convert typewriter to typographic apostrophes, as many now do). Yep, I knew Pages do that (and Word on Windows) > Macs have had this ability to easily produce proper typographic apostrophes **since 1984**, and the fact that even today, **34 years later**, Windows users must type Alt+0146 on the number pad to enter one (if their word processor or text editor doesn’t have a function to produce one) just _boggles my mind_. (And this is why I cringe when I see typewriter apostrophes in Mac software!) :-) Hehe, well it's fixed now ;) Interestingly it seems macOS UI (in french at least) uses the typographic apostrophes too ! > I'm still on High Sierra @SeanMSmith Can you please take a second and tell me if you have this bug on High Sierra too ? See here : https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/586 Many thanks ! And if you have another second, a quick look at this too : https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/pull/603 Interesting thanks ! Anything cached was fine thankfully. @dvtch I can't find much about what is precisely not allowed at login, but I can think of a couple reasons why it wouldn't work. The very first launch of Aerial needs : - network access to download the json - to create a cache directory (in the users Library/Cache) - filesystem access to said directory - to write where the cache directory is in the user's preferences. So pre login, first launch would definitely fail. Subsequent launch, I would guess when no user is login, you can't load preferences so we'd don't know where to look for the cache directory, assuming we would have access to the filesystem (I would guess not). So off the top of my head, I would guess that's not possible as is. If you can find what specifically is allowed/not allowed, maybe we could find a workaround but it would make sense to me that we don't have filesystem access at login. Last comment [there](http://osxdaily.com/2014/03/07/set-screen-saver-login-window-mac-os-x/), people seem to say that Ken Burns won't load, which would corroborate the no filesystem thing. (I would add to this that installing for all users should do most of this for you already, but I'm really not convinced filesystem would be available to Aerial, for security reasons. Might be totally wrong on that ! If you give it a shot, enable logging and post log if you have an issue) Make sense ! Thanks @LvanProosdij for clarification. > What do you mean by _"installing for all users"_ ? By default macOS "install screen savers for all users". When you double click `Aerial.saver` file after uncompressing the downloaded archive, macOS does automatically store `Aerial.saver` in `/Library/Screen Savers/` Pretty sure that's no longer the default, here it defaults to current user only when installing a screensaver on Mojave. You can override at install though. > What do you mean by "should do most of this for you already" ? Locating prefs and caches is hard coded in developers code. **Currently even if Aerial is located in `/Library/Screen Savers/` it does store it's prefs in users `~Library/Preferences/ByHost/`** Cache can be overridden manually. But that's what I meant by "most", yes. I didn't write the Preferences code so I'm not sure if it tries to use global preferences. If not it will fail but that's fixable. According to code, Aerial uses [ScreenSaverDefaults](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/screensaver/screensaverdefaults) which wraps userDefaults Using global preferences requires usage of the low level [CFPreferences](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/corefoundation/preferences_utilities) There may be some permission issue (or not, hard to tell) since we are running as a plugin to either ScreenSaverEngine or SystemPreferences (which is why Apple provides the ScreenSaverDefaults wrapper). Probably not a trivial change but if you want to explore this we definitely welcome PRs. Even without SIP ? Wow ! Well, thanks a lot for checking this @LvanProosdij ! Indeed ! On some systems, if you have a "minipreview" in syspref and press "preview" (to get the fullscreen one), ScreenSaverEngine will reuse the same instance of Aerial than the one used for the minipreview (which we really don't want). Because of this, in multi-monitor setup with mirroring mode only (!), it worked exactly once, but if you pressed preview again, Aerial would try and reuse a player from the previous time you pressed the preview button, which would crash. This seems to be a bug with Swift screensavers on MacOS that aren't getting their resources completely reloaded properly on upgrading. So, with 1.4, we use the most recent video version available (we look for them in tvos12, tvos11 and tvos10 JSONs in that order). Whether those are better or not is subjective indeed, they are more color saturated and sometimes recropped. Some are slightly less blocky too. But they are aligned in "quality" with the other video formats (HEVC 1080p and 4K) so it makes more sense for us to use the same versions independent of video format. As of right now, we don't purge the old files, though I'll mark this as something to look at for next version ! @SeanMSmith for sure, never ever delete anything behind the user's back. As part of the enhancements to the cache panel (at the very list, show how big the cache currently is), I was thinking of adding maybe some sort of menu where there would be some purging options : - Purge old/duplicate videos (there are actually some litteral duplicates, we don't download them in 1.4 but they may have been downloaded before) - Purge other formats (so if you have 4K selected, purge everything that wouldn't be played, so all 4K and all "best available format" for each video) - Purge out of rotation (mayyyybe) There are many considerations that comes with each of these, so it's not exactly a straightforward implementation. All would come with a confirmation prompt I think, some sort of list to review is a good idea although UI wise, since we're already in a sheet, slightly unsure how that would present itself (I guess a modal box). I do like the move to trash idea a lot ! Yes, it only downloads the "best available format", whatever method you use. So delete manually the videos (you can keep the 4K by filtering in finder and removing the rest, those aren't duped, but you can delete everything if you have bandwidth) and redownload -> you'll get a completely deduped directory with only best versions available. If you use the "Download All" in the menu (below the video list in main pane), you'll see the individual videos getting downloaded as the list updates itself ;) The list will tell you the status of the best available format for your preferred format only. If you switch format you'll see the list update. I had started to make a grid that showed each video in each format for the cache, but ended up scrapping it for some reason. As for versions, there's up to 5 I think. tvOS12 JSON has 3 format, tvOS10 litteraly has duplicates in it. 1.4+ never download duplicates or "outdated" versions. So back to your question, scrap your cache and redownload, it will be clean with one best file per video :) Just to give some background, what Aerial 1.4 does is : - parse the tvOS12 and grab every video urls in all formats - parse the tvOS11 and grab every video urls in all formats for what we don't yet have (there are no H.264 links here, two videos are in there that aren't in the tvOS12 url, others are all the same) - parse the tvOS10 and grab every video urls in all formats for what we don't yet have At every point, it tries to "merge" info (so for example, Liwa is only in tvOS11 JSON as 1080p HEVC and 4K HEVC, no 1080p H.264, but it's in the tvOS10 JSON as H.264, so we merge that H.264 url in the list). Merging is done by looking at the UUID of each video when possible, but we also have a list of duplicate UUID so we can merge those correctly. On top of that, there are litteral duplicates with different names and UUID that we have to exclude, and videos that are available in lower quality that gets excluded. Again on top of that, we merge extra info : - missing videos from the JSON (Dubai night 2 in 4K, Sheikh road) - the extra descriptions identifier for what's called the point of interests (when text shows up in the middle of a video, I recently relinked that for the old non 4K videos that have different IDs than those used by that list) - the better names (to replace "One, two, three") At the end, you get a perfectly deduplicated list with all the "best" urls for each of the 3 video format (when available) and that's what Aerial uses now :) As you can see on the left column, not every video is available in 4K. Only those with the "4K" label are, the oldest ones are 1080p H.264 only and you have those selected too for playback. If you strictly only want 4K, you'll have to disable the old videos. Click the action button below the list and click the "Check only 4K", this way you'll have what you expect. You can check for yourself the old files by going to the "Cache" tab and click "Show in Finder", this will show you the videos and you can open them in quicktime. Default to english with the option to localize (per my issue, there might be some displaying bugs in some non latin languages, but hard to get feedback from it, it will come soon enough when released I guess). - Added fade in/out on the videos themselves - Added preliminary detection for hardware acceleration support, and a better description based on latest findings (HEVC videos are encoded at Main10 profile which is not fully hardware accelerated pre 2017 Macs where the Intel iGPU is used) - Don't redownload the tvOS 12 .tar file if already present in cache directory per this discussion #509 - Bypassing the VideoCache mecanism when the file is already fully cached. While it's a clever trick, it had a drawback of trying to assess the file duration, generating those error on console (and a 240 KB network request on every video) : `2018-10-01 20:17:53.633735+0200 AerialApp[10827:5184263] [] [20:17:53.634] curlh_lookupAndRetainRegisteredInfoForRequestIDOnQueue signalled err=-17374 (kFigCustomURLHandlerError_RequestingClientGone) (no requestingClient for this request) at /BuildRoot/Library/Caches/com.apple.xbs/Sources/CoreMedia_frameworks/CoreMedia-2282.15/Sources/DataIO/CustomURLHandling/FigCustomURLHandling.c:1223` I think it also makes the video playback start slightly faster as a bonus. Only cached videos will be used if any. - Brought back check/uncheck all option below the list - Some preparation for bringing back tvOS 10/11 And : - Added new DownloadManager for queuing/managing simultaneous downloads (only used for JSONs so far) - Added tvOS10 & tvOS11 videos (with list merging/blacklisted dupes, etc) - Space videos are now grouped together for convenience - Now providing day/night info for tvOS11/12 videos, the day/night indicator is back in the side column in preference pane - Moved `Video Format` to main pane, renamed to `Preferred Video Format`. Closing as duplicate One of the coolest thing about the new Space screensavers on tvOS12 is that by gently pressing the remote while they play, you can get detailed information about what the camera is flying over. This is implemented by a set of timestamps and keys in the JSON, that are themselves referencing a localizedStrings bundle that is with the ressources.tar file that we now download in 1.4+. I've started implementing support to display those strings in lieu of the basic descriptions, but since those strings are localized (and will be displayed according to your MacOS locale), there are probably some text rendering issues (partially displayed, etc) in some languages that uses non latin characters. ![capture d ecran 2018-09-28 a 20 24 18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37544189/46227478-a1489c80-c35f-11e8-804e-7b76eb6bf249.jpg) So if you feel adventurous and want to help, I made a test build with that feature here : https://github.com/glouel/Aerial/releases/download/test1.41b1/Aerial.saver.zip Again, this is a test build for those who want to help debug this. Some things of note : - All the descriptions show with a 2s fade in/fade out - If you set show for 10s, the new description will pop only for 10s with fade in/fade out. If you set always, the description will stay until replaced by the new one (with a fade out/fade in again which "should" be seamless) - Land videos have only one description for the whole duration. Space videos have multiple descriptions that can be spaced by as little as 10 seconds Known issues : - The very last description will not fade out before the video gets cut - It's possible the string disappears before the end with show always, and a land video Those issues are linked to the fact that I'm currently not detecting the video duration. Please report any issue you see in your locale with a description of the issue, your mac model, and possibly a screenshot of the issue you see if it hasn't been reported already. Many thanks in advance to those who will give it a shot. Choppiness may be the memory thing, or too many video streams decoding simultaneously. Anyway, let me know if you can fix your video link. Regarding acceleration, even on my iMac with a dedicated GPU, MacOS is using the Intel QuickSync video decoding. So I doubt it's using an eGPU at all for this. QuickSync is a bunch of fixed functions units, not really "gpu decoding" so the lack of GPU power of Intel's iGPU is probably not to blame. I'd suggest you click the ? to make sure you see two green dots on HW acceleration. Also check cpu usage, CPU decoding would definitely cause choppiness on a laptop. Quick feedback, I wasn't able to reproduce your memory issue so please try to clarify it. I did find something else that probably explains the chopinness issue for some. All of the SDR HEVC 1080p and 4K videos seem to be encoded with a Main10 profile and that's an issue at least on my machine. Skylake's Gen9's MFX doesn't fully decode HEVC Main10, so it's at best "assisted" or CPU decoded. ![med-cap-07](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37544189/46312191-a4909200-c5c4-11e8-9c73-ab60f621a773.png) I'm not sure if Apple uses the GPU assist at all for HEVC on Skylake on MacOS. If I use either Quicktime or Aerial to play one of the 4K files, I see for one video playing a CPU load of 20-25% (pretty much 1 core maxed) approximately on my Core i5 6600 from the decoder task (VTDecoderXPCService). If I have multiple streams, that goes up quite fast and things start getting choppy. Same thing for 1080p HEVC although it's much lower, maybe 7%. In your specific case, you have a Kaby Lake, so theoretically, that iteration of Quicksync should handle HEVC Main10 decoding through the MFX. Could you try to see, using QuickTime, if you see a higher CPU load playing one of the 4K videos with the decoder task ? Video decoding acceleration seems to be pretty much a black box in AVPlayer, the closest thing I found is this property `preferredVideoDecoderGPURegistryID ` but Apple's documentation is... succinct : https://developer.apple.com/documentation/avfoundation/avplayer/2942616-preferredvideodecodergpuregistry Maybe one can specify to use another GPU through that. In this message https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/463#issuecomment-424744678, I assumed that MacOS prefers QuickSync when available over dGPU acceleration, which may or may not be correct. It's hard to know, really, and the function that lets you check if hardware acceleration is available (`VTIsHardwareDecodeSupported`) only seem to allow to check for codecs without a specific profile (and answers available on my iMac for HEVC) and not for the specifics (checking if Main10 decoding is available would help). Thanks for your quick answer and the video ! So, the good news is that, at least on Kaby Lake+, 4K Main10 HEVC is hardware decoded, so that's a win :) I guess I should use the CPU generation to try and refine the HEVC detection. Regarding your issue, I think it has nothing to do with Aerial. Check this thread : https://discussions.apple.com/thread/7589928 That service you see (`com.apple.photos.ImageConversionService`) is the Photos/iCloud thing, it might be trying to upload/download your pictures to iCloud or maybe convert your JPEGs to HEIF. Maybe it pops because you're in the screensaver Preferences pane, and the service thinks it can then run (as I guess it does when the screensaver is running, so it's running because of the preview... maybe ? that's a weird Apple bug if so !). Maybe try another screensaver to see if you still see that service. Regarding the `VTDecoderXPCService`, using the same 4K LA video in quicktime here, I see about 410 MB of memory usage so in the same rough ballpark to yours. That's what you should see (and if you open the sheet, you may see more because of the 2nd "preview" which is not really a preview in the same sense). In any case, try the pause thing suggested in that link, see if the service and choppiness disappears ? Your machine lacks hardware accelerated HEVC decoding so the video is decoded by the CPU (hence the high load). Please try this version and let me know, if you use 1080p H264 it should fix your load issue : https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/463#issuecomment-424407877 The first beta only had 4K support, then I added back 1080p. Because of that I kept it as default to avoid people redownloading videos. However I definitely agree, 1080p should probably even be the default for everyone (the whole 4K set takes 12.5 GB which may be an issue for a lot of people by itself). Side note, the new videos (1080p and 4K) are all using HEVC instead of H264. H.264 is still available for 1080p but I haven't added the option to use them yet. HEVC has a pretty big size advantage. On older configurations, HEVC may be an issue. In your specific case, I guess you have a dedicated GPU on your MBP (that may handle 1080p HEVC but not 4K or not 3x 4K streams). Haswell's iGPU doesn't hw decode HEVC at all, so that's probably an issue that needs fixing too for those machines and older. Ideally, we should probably detect if HEVC decoding is hardware accelerated or not too. In the case of Intel's iGPU, full HEVC decode starts with Skylake (2015). If you are using my builds from the other thread, check in the cache panel if you are using 4K. Some videos are grainy/blurry (especially space), some aren't. But if it's 4K, it should only use 4K. If you want to compare, you can go manually in the cache folder and check the videos. All the new ones you have downloaded should be ending in something like "HEVC_4K.mov" (you may also have some previous videos in that folder but they won't be used). 1080p shows as "HEVC 2K". Well, HEVC should still play on your Mac but it will be CPU decoded instead of GPU accelerated, so you may see high CPU load (see this issue https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/505 ) I've added a build here with 1080p H264 as default : https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/463#issuecomment-424407877 We'll see what we can do about detection at a later point. @BreiteSeite I tried to investigate that a bit in that issue https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/512#issuecomment-426052836 In your case, Late 2016, that's still a Skylake CPU so you only have "semi" accelerated HEVC decoding, because the videos are encoded in Main10 HEVC profile. As for your Radeon Pro 455, in theory it should have HEVC 10 bit playback, whether it is used or not, I don't know. It may not be used at all, or because you have two gpus, only some of the time. I'd suggest as I did in the linked comment checking CPU usage when playing the same video on QuickTime, see what happens ? @BreiteSeite I'm not sure that 100% means it uses the GPU for decoding. The decoding is based on fixed function units, not on the GPU itself so it's hard to say what that GPU load is (I'm not sure what sensor is used). Note that the GPU itself doesn't have to be active in order for Intel's QuickSync to be used so forcing the discrete GPU may not affect MacOS's GVA video decoding. In any case, you still have a fair bit of CPU load. I'd suggest you check with Activity Monitor, see what CPU load you have on VTDecoderXPCService with QuickTime, that would give us a good clue. @BreiteSeite Thanks ! So I'd say it's definitely not fully GPU accelerated, and probably not playing through your Polaris UVD. I guess it uses Intel's QuickSync by default, your CPU load looks close to what I have on my iMac which also lacks Main10 decoding on QuickSync (and on my GPU). I did check the GPU load thing, and as I suspected, you see a "GPU load" just from the video playback itself (I guess from the buffers). Here's what I have with QuickSync "assisted" (but not complete) HEVC decoding : If you try a 1080p H.264 video you'll probably see VTDecoderXPCService below 5%. Or the same thing with a HEVC Main (8bit) video. Ideally for those machines (2015/2016), reencoding to 8bit would fix the issue. Bit of a mess ! There are still a few things that needs to be addressed, hopefully we can put some roadmap and better track bugs after we get a new maintainer. Some random thoughts about my implementation : - In order to add H264, there's one Honk Kong video that is now ignored. This particular video isn't available in H264 in the JSON, only in HEVC, and because of the internals of the video list, I had to remove it for everyone (can't have a video missing for one format). - I have a branch that brings back tvOS11 4K screensavers. Sad thing is, and I should have checked before... they are nearly all in the tvOS12 JSON already 😅 There's one desert video (and I don't remember the other one) that aren't included in the tvOS12 JSON. Because it was a quick hack and it didn't bring much, I didn't push that branch. If the video list gets fixed (see above), we could also add back the tvOS10 videos (the originals). Those are 1080p H264 only though. - I'm pretty sure that even on my Late 2015 iMac 5K (Intel Skylake with AMD GPU), AVKit uses Intel's iGPU fixed function hw decoding (aka QuickSync) for H264, as I saw this on the console : `GVA info: Successfully connected to the Intel plugin, offline Gen9 ` I assume it is also used for HEVC too in my case (although I didn't see any such message on console). - Some discrete AMD GPUs also have H.264 and HEVC decoding, but not all of them. In my case (M2XX, Tonga), that generation only has UVD 5.0 with H.264 hw decoding, but not HEVC. HEVC came with Polaris (the 400/500 series on laptops). - Knowing what gets used will probably be pretty important in order to track bugs/crashes in the future (see https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/468 which I couldn't reproduce after a few hours of playback on my very old Sandy Bridge 2011 Macbook Air). I don't know if we can know either what is available, or what is used through an API, or if we'll have to do guesswork. Some interesting cases would be the iMac Pro (no IGP, but modern AMD GPU with H.264/HEVC decoding, which I assume is used there) or the old Mac Pros (no IGP, probably only H.264 decoding ?). - I'm pretty sure we're streaming when we shouldn't, probably on the control panel. There were a few issues raised about that, I think some cleanup around that is needed. I also added a (hidden/non implemented) checkbox to disable all streaming. - Full Offline mode should be easy to add, but will need some serious rejiggering of the manifestloader though. - A priority imo should be to stop downloading the tar/JSON all the time. We should check it weekly/monthly at best (we can give the choice through a pref). - A fade in/out for videos would be coo tool, someone had a patch but ran into some issues, mostly because in order to implement the fade out, you need accurate duration for the video. This is the kind of thing that may have been fixed in later versions of AVKit/MacOS and will need to be investigated more. - We talked with @esetnik about what would be needed for bringing back day/night, and show day/night videos depending on current time (a bit like the dynamic wallpapers on Mojave). This one is not new, it's just Apple's CDN misbehaving, I had the same issue in Safari too (maybe there's something weird though but this is stuff I haven't touched so far, checking...) Edit : Things I looked at : - forcing redirection to the final CDN url -> no change - maybe it's the old video server only (phobos) -> same issue on new one (sylvia) What happens : for some reason sometimes, we only get one data response of 100kb and nothing else, it just stops there. One thing I noticed in safari, you can see a tiny image preview before it loads the video, is it linked to that ? I think that we're missing something in our VideoLoader to detect something related to streaming but I have no idea what. I'll put this on hold for now but I'll try to get back to it. Please use cached videos in the meantime. This is driving me slightly crazy so still looking at it. Maybe getting close. So we seem to be getting an arbitrary amount of data. The data seems identical, sometimes we only get a few KB and everything is great : 15:29:49 : Starting request: { URL: https://sylvan.apple.com/Aerials/2x/Videos/LW_L001_C006_4K_SDR_HEVC.mov } 15:29:49 : Received data with length: 16031 Sometimes we get more and everything borks : 15:39:34 : Starting request: { URL: https://sylvan.apple.com/Aerials/2x/Videos/LW_L001_C006_4K_SDR_HEVC.mov } 15:39:34 : Received data with length: 712046 It looks like the beggining of a mpeg 4 stream according to mediainfo so I'm assuming the data is good, we just get more than we can handle. In a C world I would have bet on a too small buffer but hmm... Will keep checking. And I got it. Two requests are made simultaneously by Apple's AVAssetResourceLoader, the contentRequest and the dataRequest. The first one tells what type of file it is, the second brings the data. That first amount of request data gets cached while it probably shouldn't, and that messed the whole thing and subsequent request (for the rest of the data) weren't sent anymore. Anyway, fixed it by disabling some "extra" cache mechanism that tried to fullfill that request while it shouldn't (it would have been useful if we were scrubbing for example but since we don't, it's useless). Cache Aerials as they play still works correctly, and as soon as you play through a video it's persisted to disk and then you're in the "good path". Will that fix all your bugs, I don't know, but at least streaming is correctly working again and you should never see those black screen while streaming anymore. I'll post a build soonish. Closing. @djroed We know exactly why this error is being caused. It isn't a mystery. There is a bug in macOS. When you load a screensaver that is written using Swift, System Preferences loads the Swift libraries into its process. Unfortunately there are multiple copies of the Swift libraries for each release of Swift. And System Preferences will only load one set of the libraries at a time. So if you open System Preferences with a screensaver selected that needs version 1 of the Swift libraries then System Preferences will load version 1 of the libraries, but if you select a screensaver that needs another version of the libraries you will get the error saying "You cannot use the ... screen saver with this version of OS X. Please contact the vendor to get a newer version of the screen saver." The only way to get System Preferences to load a different version of the libraries is to close it and start again. But to make sure it loads the correct version of the libraries needed by Aerial, you need to open it with Aerial selected or another screensaver that uses the same version of the libraries. This is what you must have done. The "another screen saver" you mention must use the same version of the libraries that Aerial uses. So when you selected Aerial the correct version was loaded. The bug has been reported to Apple. The rdar number is 25569037. It is now one year and three weeks old. And that's why my instructions ended with "Please try this and let us know how you get on." So that if it doesn't work I can try to help people figure out why. :) You are right a few people try this and it doesn't work. My best guess is that if it doesn't work then something else is loading the Swift libraries into the System Preferences process and not just a screensaver. It's easy to confirm if this is what is happening, and even work out what is doing it. If someone follows the instructions I posted above and STILL gets the "Please contact the vendor to get a newer version of the screen saver." message, then they just need to... 1) Open Activity Monitor with SystemPreferences still showing the error 2) Select the SystemPreferences process 3) Click the Information button 4) Select the "Open Files and Ports" tab 5) Copy the files and ports information into a text editor (there will be a LOT of files listed) and search for "libswift". This will show where the Swift libraries are being loaded from. It will look something like this... ``` /Users/alistair/Library/Screen Savers/iOS Saver.saver/Contents/MacOS/iOS Saver txt /Users/alistair/Library/Screen Savers/iOS Saver.saver/Contents/Frameworks/libswiftAppKit.dylib txt /Users/alistair/Library/Screen Savers/iOS Saver.saver/Contents/Frameworks/libswiftCoreGraphics.dylib txt /Users/alistair/Library/Screen Savers/iOS Saver.saver/Contents/Frameworks/libswiftDarwin.dylib txt /Users/alistair/Library/Screen Savers/iOS Saver.saver/Contents/Frameworks/libswiftDispatch.dylib txt /Users/alistair/Library/Screen Savers/iOS Saver.saver/Contents/Frameworks/libswiftFoundation.dylib txt /Users/alistair/Library/Screen Savers/iOS Saver.saver/Contents/Frameworks/libswiftObjectiveC.dylib txt /Users/alistair/Library/Screen Savers/iOS Saver.saver/Contents/Frameworks/libswiftQuartzCore.dylib txt /Users/alistair/Library/Screen Savers/iOS Saver.saver/Contents/Frameworks/libswiftSecurity.dylib txt ``` Alternatively they can copy and paste that info from the "Open file and ports" tab and send it to alistairmcmillan75@gmail.com and I'll look through it myself to work out what is causing the issue. I'm tired of explaining this bug. Last time. Never again. There are multiple versions of the Swift libraries. Version 1.0, 1.1, 1.2, 2.0 and 3.0. System Preferences will only load one version of the Swift libraries. Once it has loaded one version it will not load another. Whichever version of the Swift libraries it loads first, that's it until you close System Preferences, the process dies and start again from scratch. So if you open System Preferences and load a screensaver that uses version 1.0 of the Swift libraries, System Preferences loads version 1.0 of the Swift libraries. And then any screensaver that uses 1.1 or 1.2 or 2.0 or 3.0 of the Swift libraries will show that "You cannot use the XXX screen saver with this version of macOS. Please contact the vendor to get a newer version of the screen saver." error. Similarly if you open System Preferences to a screensaver that uses version 2.0 of the Swift libraries, System Preferences loads version 2.0 of the libraries and then any screensaver that uses 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 or 3.0 will display the "You cannot use the XXX screen saver with this version of macOS. Please contact the vendor to get a newer version of the screen saver." error. And so on and so forth for every combination. If you would like to help please log a bug with Apple [here](https://bugreport.apple.com) or [here](http://www.apple.com/feedback/) or bug an Apple employee on Twitter or phone your Senator or send smoke signals or whatever. The reason for this error is that there are multiple versions of the Swift libraries, and you can get a situation where macOS (and OSX before it) loads a specific version of the Swift libraries for something and then tries to run software written in Swift with those libraries even if they aren't the correct version. So if you're getting this error in full screen then something must have loaded a version of the Swift libraries into the process that draws the screensaver full screen. A fresh copy fixed it. @jsm296 People are having this problem because there are multiple versions of the Swift libraries and System Preferences loads the Swift libraries once. It doesn't unload them and reload them for different plugins (it treats screen savers as plugins). So if you load a screen saver first that uses a version of the plugins that Swift doesn't use, then when you select Aerial it fails to run because System Preferences still has that wrong version loaded. That's why selecting Aerial, closing and reopening System Preferences enables Aerial to run. Cause you're making sure System Preferences loads the right Swift libraries first. This "cannot use the Aerial screen saver with this version of OS X" error is caused by a bug in OS X. http://alistairmcmillan.github.io/2016/04/25/OSX-Swift-screensaver-bug.html @AlexPasternak Select Aerial, close System Preferences, re-open System Preferences, the preview should now work. Let us know if it doesn't. I logged a bug with Apple about it ten months ago but they haven't responded. radr://25569037 for anyone that's interested. @fahimisediqa 1) Open System Preferences and select Aerial. 2) Leave Aerial selected and close System Preferences. 3) Reopen System Preferences, the error should be gone. Let us know how you get on. As I mentioned on another issue. If these commands were incorporated into the screensaver, the only way for them to take effect is for the screensaver to run. And if the screensaver is running, then people don't see this error. Or to phrase it the other way around. This error means that macOS couldn't run the screensaver. If it can't run the screensaver then the commands wouldn't run. The only way to fix this right now is by nagging Apple to get them to fix the bug in macOS. @kennyluk @MichaelDimmitt It's not a permissions issue. There are multiple versions of Swift. Swift applications including screensavers still include their version of the Swift libraries inside their bundle because of the different versions. When macOS loads a Swift binary (for example when it loads a screensaver bundle into the System Preferences application) it loads the appropriate Swift libraries for the version of Swift that the binary was compiled against. If you then load another Swift binary (i.e. another screensaver) macOS does not attempt to load the appropriate Swift libraries because it already has Swift libraries loaded. Hence the error message. You can confirm this by using Activity Monitor to look at the files loaded into the System Preferences application when you have a Swift screensaver selected. When you select a second Swift screensaver that was compiled against a different version you'll see that System Preferences doesn't unload the Swift libraries from the bundle of the first screensaver, they stay loaded and macOS tries and fails to load the second Swift screensaver and link them to those incompatible Swift libraries resulting in the "You cannot use the Aerial screen saver with this version of OS X". This is a bug in macOS. It is not a permissions problem. Closing as this is solved now thankfully ! Thanks for the kind words. Should have thought of that. :) Perhaps (for the future) a button in Aerial's Time pane to "Get current coordinates", so that any permissions dialog will appear only when the user has manually requested the current coordinates. @glouel So does it give you the correct coordinates? Or do you have to get them from maps? I'm still on High Sierra (I have a Fusion drive that will be converted to APFS upon upgrading to Mojave, and out of an abundance of caution, I'm waiting until at least 10.14.1), so I won't be able to test that. @glouel thanks again for this addition. This should put this issue to rest for now, as I feel this is a good compromise, without adding too much overhead/user interaction. :) Yep works fine nice addition >If that works well, I might move that option up above night shift in the dialog, as I think it's better for most people to be able to calculate using your favorite method. I like it better to Getting my current coordinates works well in High Sierra (and the coordinates are very close to those shown in Apple Maps - they diverge at the fourth decimal place, which is close enough). Three corrections: 1. Change "Today's" to "Today’s" (i.e. use a proper apostrophe) 2. Don't capitalize "sunrise" and "sunset" 3. More importantly, when the user has chosen to calculate from Civil, Nautical, or Astronomical, then change "Today’s sunrise" to "Today’s dawn" and change "Today’s sunset" to "Today’s dusk". The help text should probably also be changed to make clear that Civil, Nautical, and Astronomical are ways of calculating the time of dawn and of dusk, not of sunrise and sunset. Perhaps something like the following: There are two ways to calculate the sunset and sunrise time: - Strict (0°): Calculate when the center of the Sun crosses the horizon - Official (0.83°) : Calculate when the Sun completely crosses the horizon Or instead of sunrise and sunset, you can pick from three options for the time of dawn and dusk: - Civil (6°) : Calculate when the natural sunlight stops/starts requiring artificial light compensation - Nautical (12°) : Calculate when stars stop/start being seen - Astronomical (18°) : Calculate the point when the sun no longer interferes with astronomical observations (Note also that I have suggested swapping "start/stop" for "stop/start" in the help text above to correspond with dawn/dusk, adding "center of" to the definition of Strict, and correcting the spelling of "interfere".) > > 1. Change "Today's" to "Today’s" (i.e. use a proper apostrophe) > > Is that the default apostrophe on QWERTY keyboard ? The default apostrophe on a QWERTY keyboard is “ ' ”, what is sometimes called a “typewriter apostrophe.” See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apostrophe#Typographic_form and the following two sections, in particular https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apostrophe#Entering_apostrophes. On a Mac, pressing Option-Shift-] is the easiest way to type a proper “typographic apostrophe” (if your word processor doesn’t automatically convert typewriter to typographic apostrophes, as many now do). Macs have had this ability to easily produce proper typographic apostrophes **since 1984**, and the fact that even today, **34 years later**, Windows users must type Alt+0146 on the number pad to enter one (if their word processor or text editor doesn’t have a function to produce one) just _boggles my mind_. (And this is why I cringe when I see typewriter apostrophes in Mac software!) :-) Aerial 1.4.3, macOS 10.14, iMac 16 GB, single monitor setup. Was not preview, crashed during screensaver playback. Reproductible : - For testing I removed Aerial cache folder. - Open Control Panel, Screen Saver, Aerial, Screen Saver Options…, Videos, Check All, Download All. Keep panel open. - Process `Desktop Picture (System Preferences)` memory usage keeps growing and growing while downloading file after file. - The more files are loaded the more memory is used, GB adds to GB, computer starts to swap, everything gets slower and slower. An 8 GB Mac will completely freeze. - Quitting the Control Panel frees memory. ![screenshot 2018-10-23 at 17 37 01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6991846/47372539-47cb5780-d6ea-11e8-9d57-275b0a4decfa.png) ![screenshot 2018-10-23 at 17 59 40](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6991846/47374406-25d3d400-d6ee-11e8-8b77-d94f3a50d8a4.png) Great news! That may also explain reports of slowed down Mac (and sometimes freezes), high CPU usage, etc. I'm looking to deploy this to a lab of AD bound Macs. My settings are such that while a user is logged in, there isn't really a point of a screensaver because for security reasons, users are auto-logged out after 10 minutes of inactivity anyway. Where I want to utilise Aerial is at the login Window where there is more likelihood of screen burn. My MDM service has options to pick which screen saver to use at the login window but when I point it to /Library/Screen Savers/Aerial.saver - nothing actually loads. I have read that not all screen savers necessarily work before login. That might simply be the case here? Is Aerial likely to work in this scenario or should I just pass on the idea? @dvtch I see no reason why Aerial would not have network access and filesystem access if triggered at login (with no user logged in). I think you should investigate to move all files (prefs, cache, etc.) from user profile (`~/Library`) to main Library (`/Library`). BTW Aerial is located there… `/Library/Screen Savers/` that's why it should be able to run at login screen. This would also avoid storing copies of cached videos in each user profile. Leaving no choice for users to choose a cache directory, just storing cache in `/Library/Caches/com.JohnCoates.Aerial/`. Preferences would be global, no per user preferences. > Last comment [there](http://osxdaily.com/2014/03/07/set-screen-saver-login-window-mac-os-x/), people seem to say that Ken Burns won't load, which would corroborate the no filesystem thing. > Any of the image slideshow screen savers work, and a few of the Quartz Composer screen savers too Because images and files are located in `/Library/` or `/System/Library/` macOS images for slideshow screen savers are located here `/Library/Screen Savers/Default Collections` > but third party screensavers are not supported, those storing prefs and/or files in user library `~/Library` can't be supported. > and neither are RSS feeds, iPhoto based slideshows, or iTunes artwork. because they need files located in user library or user folders. > I would add to this that installing for all users should do most of this for you already What do you mean by _"installing for all users"_ ? By default macOS "install screen savers for all users". When you double click `Aerial.saver` file after uncompressing the downloaded archive, macOS does automatically store `Aerial.saver` in `/Library/Screen Savers/` What do you mean by "should do most of this for you already" ? Locating prefs and caches is hard coded in developers code. Currently even if Aerial is located in `/Library/Screen Savers/` it does store it's prefs in users `~Library/Preferences/ByHost/` > Pretty sure that's no longer the default, here it defaults to current user only when installing a screensaver on Mojave. You can override at install though. On macOS Mojave the user is asked if he want "user only" or "all users" install. If the screen saver was already installed, macOS just update it without asking location. ![screenshot 2018-10-23 at 12 56 08](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6991846/47356177-931e3f80-d6c3-11e8-86e6-b0c4b12ea9f3.png) > I didn't write the Preferences code so I'm not sure if it tries to use global preferences. If not it will fail but that's fixable. Solution would be to locate prefs and caches according to Aerial.saver location, user library or main library. > but if you want to explore this we definitely welcome PRs I haven't coded since GS OS and MacOS 9 ;-) I was planning to put my hands in code again, learning Swift. Will do that in a few weeks when getting my new Mac. But don't expect any brilliant coding before long :-) Further reading, I just don't think it is possible and that is through more of Apple's sandboxing than a shortcoming of Aerial. There are too many variables since pre-configured preferences are part of this deployment to ensure cache location and such are set automatically on each client. That side of it, the deployment-side, took some tweaking with munki/outset scripting but I got it deploying the settings per client quite nicely. Aerial would load during a desktop session and applied all the settings I required. It's just that this isn't the kind of screen saver which can load at the login window, is all. I did some testing, macOS (Mojave) simply do not even try to execute any third party screensaver while at login screen. Even if locating the third party screensaver in `/System/Library/Screen Savers` and disabling System Integrity Protection (SIP). It's probably for security reasons. It may save you some time so that I don't have to create a pull request every time. ## Known Issues Before logging an issue please check if one of the problems you are experiencing is mentioned here. If the issue you are experiencing isn't covered here, then please delete this content and tell us about the problem you are experiencing or the feature you'd like to request. ### "You cannot use the Aerial screen saver with this version of OS X." message If you get a message saying `You cannot use the Aerial screen saver with this version of OS X. Please contact the vendor to get a newer version of the screen saver.` that is a known bug with macOS that was reported to Apple in April 2016 as [rdar://25569037](http://openradar.appspot.com/25569037). As of November 2017 the bug is still not fixed. To work around the bug: * Select the Aerial screensaver in System Preferences * Close System Preferences with Aerial selected * Reopen System Preferences and the preview should work now ### Mac won't sleep with Aerial as screensaver If your Mac won't sleep while Aerial is the selected screensaver, then you probably have an older version of Aerial installed. Download the latest verson of Aerial here: https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/ Make sure to check both locations for the old version, it can be installed to `/Library/Screen Savers` and `/User/YOURUSERNAME/Library/Screen Savers`. ### Corrupted playback If you are getting corrupted playback when the screensaver starts then that is a new bug in macOS High Sierra. It appears to be a problem with the Intel drivers in High Sierra. As a workaround tick the "Show with clock" option as that seems to eliminate the corruption for the moment. Discussed extensively here: https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/377 ### No playback If you are getting a crossed out play icon instead of the preview or the videos just never seem to load, please check that a firewall or proxy isn't blocking the screensavers access to the videos. Trying the following two URLs in a web browser might show if they are blocked. If you are on a Macbook you can also try caching the videos on another network to test whether it is your network provider that is blocking access. http://a1.phobos.apple.com/us/r1000/000/Features/atv/AutumnResources/videos/comp_GL_G004_C010_v03_6Mbps.mov http://a1.v2.phobos.apple.com.edgesuite.net/us/r1000/000/Features/atv/AutumnResources/videos/comp_GL_G004_C010_v03_6Mbps.mov Also tried reinstall and restart options, no go! The API only allows to test for HEVC, not specifically HEVC Main10 profile (so it answers yes on my iMac despite not being supported). I can make it green again if you think that's better, but leaving the may (I think the extra description I gave should be enough warning) We could consider implementing a HEVC Main10 hardware whitelist and fallback to "may" since it seems that we don't have a good way to determine the support level programmatically. Alternatively, maybe we can implement a heuristic to predict support. E.g. play one of the cached videos for 30s and monitor CPU usage of the VTDecoderXPCService. The difference between partial and full Main10 support is significant. I get 1.4% CPU during 4k HEVC Main10 playback on my 2018 MBP. Part of the motivation for this is to launch Aerial with a sensible set of defaults for the system. A large majority of issues filed on the project are related to playback performance problems due to missing hardware support. HEVC Main10 causes major performance issues on all hardware without full support so I think we should default Aerial to 1080p H.264 (or maybe 1080p HEVC) on any device which fails the whitelist. (Speaking as a writer and editor, I have to say that your English seems better than that of most of my fellow native English speakers!) Grammatically, "Preview streaming is disabled" and "Video preview streaming is disabled" are equally correct, but I do think the longer form is needlessly wordy; "Preview streaming is disabled" is just as clear and better for being shorter. Personally, I too dislike "macOS"; medial capitals (aka "InterCaps") in English, especially when the first letter is uncapitalized, strike me as silly and pretentious. Alas, marketing creatures are addicted to them. "Check Only Cached" and "Check Cached Only" (likewise "Check Only 4K" and "Check 4K Only") are equally correct grammatically, and sound equally good to me. (The only variation I would avoid is "Only Check Cached", where the "only" modifies "check" rather than "cached".) Thank you for your most refreshing attention to detail! It's fixed in the beta version: https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/tag/v1.4beta9 Fix minor typo 🤭 ## Known Issues Before logging an issue please check if one of the problems you are experiencing is mentioned here. If the issue you are experiencing isn't covered here, then please delete this content and tell us about the problem you are experiencing or the feature you'd like to request. ### "You cannot use the Aerial screen saver with this version of OS X." message If you get a message saying `You cannot use the Aerial screen saver with this version of OS X. Please contact the vendor to get a newer version of the screen saver.` that is a known bug with macOS that was reported to Apple in April 2016 as [rdar://25569037](http://openradar.appspot.com/25569037). As of November 2017 the bug is still not fixed. To work around the bug: * select the Aerial screensaver in System Preferences * close System Preferences with Aerial selected * reopen System Preferences and the preview should work now ### Mac won't sleep with Aerial as screensaver If your Mac won't sleep while Aerial is the selected screensaver, then you probably have an older version of Aerial installed. Download the latest verson of Aerial here: https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/ Make sure to check both locations for the old version, it can be installed to `/Library/Screen Savers` and `/User/YOURUSERNAME/Library/Screen Savers`. ### Corrupted playback If you are getting corrupted playback when the screensaver starts then that is a new bug in macOS High Sierra. It appears to be a problem with the Intel drivers in High Sierra. As a workaround tick the "Show with clock" option as that seems to eliminate the corruption for the moment. Discussed extensively here: https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/377 ### No playback If you are getting a crossed out play icon instead of the preview or the videos just never seem to load, please check that a firewall or proxy isn't blocking the screensavers access to the videos. Trying the following two URLs in a web browser might show if they are blocked. If you are on a Macbook you can also try caching the videos on another network to test whether it is your network provider that is blocking access. http://a1.phobos.apple.com/us/r1000/000/Features/atv/AutumnResources/videos/comp_GL_G004_C010_v03_6Mbps.mov http://a1.v2.phobos.apple.com.edgesuite.net/us/r1000/000/Features/atv/AutumnResources/videos/comp_GL_G004_C010_v03_6Mbps.mov The screen saver works great for me even on Mojave, but when I open it up and go to make a chance, I press "Done" but nothing happens. When I first installed the beta of Aerial for Mojave and tvOS 12 screen saver support, I was greeted with slideshow performance on my 3-display 2013 MacBook Pro. This all cleared up when I switched from the new 4K default back to 1080p - my poor MacBook with integrated graphics can't push that much video apparently. However, the only reason I knew that toggle was there was because I'd been reading a few issue threads in here. I've now downgraded to v1.4 again. ## Known Issues Before logging an issue please check if one of the problems you are experiencing is mentioned here. If the issue you are experiencing isn't covered here, then please delete this content and tell us about the problem you are experiencing or the feature you'd like to request. ### "You cannot use the Aerial screen saver with this version of OS X." message If you get a message saying `You cannot use the Aerial screen saver with this version of OS X. Please contact the vendor to get a newer version of the screen saver.` that is a known bug with macOS that was reported to Apple in April 2016 as [rdar://25569037](http://openradar.appspot.com/25569037). As of November 2017 the bug is still not fixed. To work around the bug: * select the Aerial screensaver in System Preferences * close System Preferences with Aerial selected * reopen System Preferences and the preview should work now ### Mac won't sleep with Aerial as screensaver If your Mac won't sleep while Aerial is the selected screensaver, then you probably have an older version of Aerial installed. Download the latest verson of Aerial here: https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/releases/ Make sure to check both locations for the old version, it can be installed to `/Library/Screen Savers` and `/User/YOURUSERNAME/Library/Screen Savers`. ### Corrupted playback If you are getting corrupted playback when the screensaver starts then that is a new bug in macOS High Sierra. It appears to be a problem with the Intel drivers in High Sierra. As a workaround tick the "Show with clock" option as that seems to eliminate the corruption for the moment. Discussed extensively here: https://github.com/JohnCoates/Aerial/issues/377 ### No playback If you are getting a crossed out play icon instead of the preview or the videos just never seem to load, please check that a firewall or proxy isn't blocking the screensavers access to the videos. Trying the following two URLs in a web browser might show if they are blocked. If you are on a Macbook you can also try caching the videos on another network to test whether it is your network provider that is blocking access. http://a1.phobos.apple.com/us/r1000/000/Features/atv/AutumnResources/videos/comp_GL_G004_C010_v03_6Mbps.mov http://a1.v2.phobos.apple.com.edgesuite.net/us/r1000/000/Features/atv/AutumnResources/videos/comp_GL_G004_C010_v03_6Mbps.mov Really appreciate the work you do, awesome screensaver. It fixed for me when updating to Mojave. Thank you! If videos are not cached, this screensaver streams enormous files over network. Imagine you are traveling, getting your internet via tethering / personal hotspot and suddenly screen saver turned on your laptop - it can it up hundreds of megabytes/gigabytes of data before you realize it. That is dangerous. There should be an option to disable streaming videos unless you are on wifi (non-hotspot one). Yes you can cache videos, but - most people may not realize they have to. Also: the current cache feature downloads ALL videos, which now eats up gigabytes on your drive. It should be possible to only download select ones (just like you can select which ones you want to play). There are third-party utilities designed to trim data consumption. A temporary workaround might be to install something like [TripMode](https://www.tripmode.ch/) which I use personally for this purpose. I tried using the fix below, and it did not work.
